DOC.HEAD: $Adv 28
For Release PMs Thurs Dec 28 and Thereafter
Noriega: Cloistered Fugitive Picks Own Prison
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Temporarily, at least, Manuel Antonio Noriega picked his own prison by taking refuge at the Vatican embassy in Panama City _ where Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney thinks the ousted military boss might be a long-term resident. That's not what the administration wants, but worse things could happen, and have. So long as the deposed military boss of Panama is a cloistered fugitive, he is isolated, silenced and confined to small compound, living in a spare, single room. Despite Washington's sharp demands that the Vatican turn over Noriega, the U.S. stake to the right of embassy refuge seems more important than his case, so long as he is out of power and neutralized. American embassies sometimes have been havens for dissenters, notably in Cold War Hungary and now Beijing. U.S. officials argue that Noriega should not be granted asylum because he is a common criminal, not a political fugitive. In his case there is solid evidence of it, but totalitarian governments have no difficulty constructing criminal charges against their dissenters. Chinese dissident Fang Lizhi and his wife took refuge in the American embassy in Beijing more than six months ago, after the government crushed the democracy movement and began a purge of its leaders. He's still there, despite repeated protests from the Chinese, who say the United States is interfering in their internal affairs. For 15 years, Cardinal Josef Mindszenty lived in asylum in the U.S. Embassy in Budapest. He had been freed from a Communist prison in the Hungarian uprising of 1956, and took refuge at the embassy after the Soviet Union put down that rebellion. The Vatican finally was able to arrange his release to the West in 1971. Embassies are considered to be the territory of the nations they represent, and when they choose to grant haven, even the most dictatorial of regimes have accepted it. Now, as Cheney said, lawyers and diplomats are trying to figure out what happens next in the Noriega case. He left open the possibility that it could be nothing. Cheney said Tuesday that the embassy is surrounded, with no way out for Noriega and no way in for U.S. authorities. ``It could be that they'll have a long-term resident in their embassy in Panama City,'' he said. Noriega would hardly seem a welcome guest; church leaders including Monsignor Jose Sebastian Laboa, the papal nuncio in Panama City, had long been critics of the general's regime. The Vatican embassy had been a refuge for Noriega opponents when they needed one. Unless there is a deal to let Noriega go to exile rather than to U.S. trial, the ousted dictator can keep hiding, but he can't run. ``At present, if he leaves the embassy under any circumstances, he will in fact be arrested by U.S. forces and returned to the United States,'' Cheney said Tuesday. Embassy refuge does not apply outside an embassy compound, so as soon as Noriega stepped outside guarded Vatican mission, he could be seized. The way around that would be a diplomatic deal to let him go into exile. It would have to be distant and silent, lest he regain his voice and try to incite his supporters against the new government. For all the demands that Noriega go on drug trial, the administration had been willing as recently as October to let him go into exile without prosecution if he yielded power. The Vatican has no extradition agreement with the United States so if the church decided Noriega should be expelled from the diplomatic mission, it would be to the custody of the Panamanian government. The Panamanian constitution forbids the extradition of any citizen. Guillermo Endara, the new president installed with American protection after Noriega was ousted, said if his government had custody, he could not deliver the dictator for U.S. drug trial. The fledgling Endara government, apparent winner of the May elections Noriega annulled, needs to establish itself and display a power to govern independent of the United States. Yielding up Noriega would be counterproductive. But the Endara government could put him on trial as a killer; there have been U.S. hints that prosecution in Panama might be acceptable. Until and unless the diplomats find a solution, Noriega presumably stays put, a captive in spare surroundings that mock the luxuries of his days in power, the cash, cocaine and voodoo cults said to have been his lifestyle.
Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 25 years.
